{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = F-84 Thunderstreak incident |partof = the [[Cold War]] |image = Airforce Museum Berlin-Gatow 76.JPG |image_size = 300px |alt=A camouflaged jet aircraft with a red ring around its nose intake, on display |caption = A F-84 Thunderstreak of the [[German Air Force]] (''Luftwaffe'') |date = 14 September 1961 |place = Near Berlin, [[East Germany]] |combatant1 = {{flagu|West Germany}} |combatant2 = {{flagu|Soviet Union|1955}} |commander1 = [[Siegfried Barth]] |commander2 = [[Ivan Konev]] |units1 = [[Jagdbombergeschwader 32|JaBoG 32]] |units2 = [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany|Western Group of Forces]] |result = West German fighters landed safely }} The '''1961 F-84 Thunderstreak incident''', occurring on 14 September 1961, was an incident during the [[Cold War (1953–1962)|Cold War]], in which two [[Republic F-84F Thunderstreak]] [[fighter-bomber]]s of [[Jagdbombergeschwader 32|''JaBoG 32'']] of the [[German Air Force]] (''Luftwaffe'') crossed into East German [[airspace]] because of a navigational error, before landing at [[Berlin Tegel Airport]]. The two planes successfully evaded a large number of Soviet fighter planes by finding cover in a heavy layer of clouds,<ref name="Spiegel" >[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-45139958.html STRAUSS-BEFEHL: Bier-Order 61] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 9 May 1962, accessed: 30 November 2010</ref> but also by the actions of an airman at the [[United States Air Force]] air route traffic control center at [[Berlin Tempelhof Airport]] who ordered the planes on to Berlin rather than forcing them to turn around and face the pursuing fighter planes.<ref name="Fifty" /> The event came at a historically difficult time in relations between the two Germanies. Only a month before, the [[Berlin Wall]] had been built, which completely cut off West Berlin from surrounding East Germany and from [[East Berlin]]. It also came three days before the [[West German federal election, 1961|West German federal election]], held on 17 September 1961.<ref name="Spiegel" />
==Background== At the time, violations of airspace at the border between West and East Germany were common, with, on average, two aircraft a month belonging to members of the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organisation]] (NATO) crossing into Eastern airspace while a much larger number of Soviet planes crossed into that of West Germany. There were 38 violations of West Germany's air space by Soviet aircraft in a period of just four weeks between August and September 1961. Some of the violations were deliberate, to determine the opposite side's reaction, while others were by mistake, caused by the difficulty in determining the border line from the air.<ref name="Monat" >[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-45141349.html LUFTZWISCHENFALL: Zweimal monatlich] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 29 August 1962, accessed: 30 November 2010</ref>
Between the end of the Second World War and the [[German reunification]], West German planes were not permitted to fly to West Berlin, regardless of whether they were civilian or military aircraft. The three existing [[West Berlin Air Corridor|air corridors]] to the city were only open to planes from the three wartime [[Western Bloc|Western Allies]]: the United States, France and the United Kingdom.<ref name="Tages" >[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/angriffshoehe-800/394316.html Angriffshöhe 800] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]'', published: 2 March 2003, accessed: 30 November 2010</ref>
==Incident== On 14 September 1961, under the code name ''Checkmate'', the [[NATO]] high command mobilised the air forces of France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, and West Germany for the purpose of an [[military exercise|exercise]]. As part of this exercise, the ''[[Jagdbomber]]''s of ''[[Jagdbombergeschwader 32|Jagdbombergeschwader (JaBoG) 32]]'', based at [[Lechfeld Airbase]], south of [[Augsburg]], were to fly a triangular route from [[Würzburg]] to [[Laon]] and then to [[Memmingen]].<ref name="Spiegel" />
Two F-84 fighter-bombers, flown by [[Feldwebel]] Peter Pfefferkorn and [[Unteroffizier|Stabsunteroffizier]] Hans Eberl,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=n6qRFggA1sMC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=Pfefferkorn+Eberl+14+September+1961&source=bl&ots=DmhvySvrU0&sig=fafOuilSu-d-gI-tp-thRCLE1m4&hl=en&ei=lOL1TKfHN4nprAfn0p32Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Pfefferkorn%20Eberl%2014%20September%201961&f=false Krieg um Berlin?: die sowjetische Militär- und Sicherheitspolitik] {{de icon}} google book review, author: Matthias Uhl, accessed: 1 December 2010</ref> lost their course in the process of flying this route, with the compass on Pfefferkorn's plane misreading by between 40 and 60 degrees. Additionally, a strong westerly wind was greater in strength than had been forecasted. On their way from Würzburg to Laon, the two pilots had become so disoriented that they mistook [[Liège]] in Belgium for [[Reims]] in France.<ref name="Spiegel" />
Shortly after, the pair were picked up by NATO radar stations near [[Warburg]], in southern [[Westphalia]], heading east, in the direction of [[Königs Wusterhausen]], south of Berlin. The two pilots missed a radio call from the radar stations advising them to turn around because they were talking to each other, trying to establish their location.<ref name="Spiegel" />
It was only when reaching a position north of [[Leipzig]], deep within East German air space, that Pfefferkorn sent a [[Mayday (distress signal)|Mayday]] signal, which was picked up, to their surprise, by the French-controlled airport at Tegel in [[West Berlin]], which gave them permission to land. The planes had initially not been noticed by the radar operator at the [[Berlin Tempelhof Airport]] because he was concentrating on an incoming [[Pan American World Airways|Pan Am]] [[Douglas DC-6]]. By the time they were noticed, the pair were being unsuccessfully chased by a large number of Soviet fighter aircraft. An airman in the Berlin Air Route Traffic Control Center ordered the two pilots not to turn around and face the pursuing fighter planes but instead to head for the Tegel airport as it had a longer runway than Tempelhof and was more suitable for jets.<ref name="Fifty">[http://www.50jahre-jabog32.de/Leseproben_50_Jahre_Jagdbombergeschwader_32.pdf 50 Jahre Jagdbombergeschwader 32] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718193436/http://www.50jahre-jabog32.de/Leseproben_50_Jahre_Jagdbombergeschwader_32.pdf |date=18 July 2011 }} {{de icon}} 50 Years Jagdbombergeschwader 32, accessed; 2 December 2010</ref> Because of the actions of this airman and the heavy cloud cover, which the two pilots used to conceal themselves, Pfefferkorn and Eberl escaped the pursuing Soviet aircraft and successfully landed their planes without further incident at Tegel.<ref name="Spiegel" />
==Reaction== ===International=== Immediately after the two aircraft landed, the French authorities at Tegel airport explained to the Soviet authorities in East Berlin that, because of technical difficulties, an [[emergency landing]] of the two planes had been absolutely necessary.<ref name="Spiegel" />
The then-West German [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)|Minister of Defence]], [[Franz-Josef Strauß]], apologised to the Soviet ambassador in [[Bonn]] for the incident, sending his secretary of state, [[Volkmar Hopf]]. The government of the Soviet Union remained silent for a number of days with regards to the incident, before officially protesting against the West German "provocation" and threatening to shoot down any aircraft involved if the incident was repeated.<ref name="Spiegel" />
The Soviet air command in East Germany was less than impressed with the 'unpunished' flight of two Western fighter planes through their airspace. However, it chose to blame bad weather for the incident rather than the failure of its ground control to guide the Soviet fighter planes on to the West German ones.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=RYYuSGcwq5AC&pg=PA101&lpg=PA101&dq=Pfefferkorn+and+Eberl&source=bl&ots=VHqzsIhtcf&sig=by3WlbzluCGCPMVwWI0WHSU6Fwc&hl=en&ei=8P70TIfGFsGecfmj4dcE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Pfefferkorn%20and%20Eberl&f=false Vor dem Abgrund: die Streitkräfte der USA und der UdSSR] {{de icon}} google book review, author: Dimitrij N. Filippovych, accessed: 30 November 2010</ref>
===Domestic=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-2005-0033, Josef Kammhuber retusche.jpg|thumb|200px|Josef Kammhuber]] [[Willy Brandt]], the leader of the opposition [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]] in the upcoming federal elections, and the mayor of West Berlin, questioned how the two pilots could be put in a situation where they would be forced to violate international conventions in a time of strained relations between the East and the West. Initially, Strauß announced a stringent investigation into the incident; instead, however, he and [[Josef Kammhuber]], [[Inspector of the Air Force]], transferred the commander of ''JaBoG 32'', [[Oberstleutnant]] [[Siegfried Barth]], and announced that any commander whose unit committed a violation of international borders would be immediately replaced.<ref name="Spiegel" />
When Kammhuber announced this order at Lechfeld the following day, it was dubbed ''Bier Order 61'' (''Beer Order 61'') because it was formulated late at night over drinks between Kammhuber and Strauß. Barth, commander of ''JaBoG 32'', was not questioned with regard to the incident, and was not allowed to speak during Kammhuber's visit. Instead, [[Generalleutnant]] [[Martin Harlinghausen]], Barth's superior officer, who had once, in 1944, stood up to [[Hermann Göring]], spoke for Barth and demanded a proper investigation.<ref name="Spiegel" />
Two weeks later, Harlinghausen was forced into early retirement. The non-commissioned officers of ''JaBoG 32'' sent a letter to Strauß requesting that Barth should retain his command, without receiving any answer. Eventually, a proper investigation was conducted which found Barth to be innocent, a result unacceptable to Kammhuber, who initiated a second investigation that found the ''Oberstleutnant'' partly at fault. A third investigation followed, which again found Barth to be innocent. Oberstleutnant Barth then lodged an official complaint against Franz-Josef Strauß. Strauß, as minister of defence, ordered all witnesses in the case - Generals Kammhuber, Harlinghausen, [[Werner Panitzki]] and [[Werner Streib]] as well as Lieutenant Colonels [[Walter Krupinski]] and [[Walter Grasemann]] - [[gag order|not to speak]], as they were all military personnel and therefore under his command. Nevertheless, his conduct in dismissing Barth was found to be at fault, and the latter had to be reinstated in his position. Strauß, however, ignored this decision until [[Hellmuth Heye]], [[Ombudsman]] for the Military, forced him to accept it.<ref name="Spiegel" /> Strauß himself was later forced to resign from his post as Minister of Defence, in the wake of the [[Spiegel scandal|''Spiegel'' scandal]] in 1962. Kammhuber retired from his post in the same year.
==Aftermath== Upon arrival at Tegel, the two planes were immediately hidden in [[hangar]]s and journalists were prohibited from taking pictures of them.<ref name="Fifty" /> For years after, it was believed that the two planes had been repainted as aircraft of the [[United States Air Force]] and returned to West Germany by USAF pilots, or that they had been disassembled and transported back to the West in pieces.<ref name="Tages" /> The arrival of two massive [[Douglas C-124 Globemaster II|Douglas C-124]] at Tegel from [[Frankfurt am Main]] also fuelled speculations that the two F-84s would be transported back in these aircraft.<ref name="Fifty" /> Another theory (which turned out to be true) held that the two aircraft were hidden by the French authorities at Tegel and, later, buried at the airfield, where they were accidentally rediscovered in the 1970s.<ref>[http://www.burgmannschaft.info/forum/upload/showthread.php?t=1117 Luftraumverletzungen und -zwischenfälle über dem Gebiet der DDR]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{de icon}}, accessed: 30 November 2010</ref>
In an exhibition at the ''[[Luftwaffenmuseum der Bundeswehr|Luftwaffenmuseum Berlin-Gatow]]'' in 2006, pictures of the two buried and then rediscovered Thunderstreaks at Tegel were shown, finally clearing up the question of what became of the two planes.<ref name="Fifty" />
The pilots of the two Thunderstreaks, Pfefferkorn and Eberl, were banned from flying and transferred to the ground crew at Lechfeld.<ref name="Monat" /> The F-84F Thunderstreak, in service with the ''Jagdbombergeschwader 32'' since inception of the unit on 22 July 1958, was phased out of service on 13 July 1966, the ''Geschwader'' having accumulated over 80,000 flight hours with the planes.<ref>[http://www.luftwaffe.de/portal/a/luftwaffe/kcxml/04_Sj9SPykssy0xPLMnMz0vM0Y_QjzKLNzKI9zAJBsmB2e5ezvqRcNGglFR9b31fj_zcVP0A_YLciHJHR0VFAN5emug!/delta/base64xml/L2dJQSEvUUt3QS80SVVFLzZfMjBfT0tD?yw_contentURL=%2F01DB060000000001%2FW27G5DLE422INFODE%2Fcontent.jsp ''Jagdbombergeschwader 32'' website – History] {{de icon}} accessed: 30 November 2010</ref>
===1962 incident=== [[File:Hawker Sea Hawks of the West German Marineflieger in August 1958.jpg|thumb|right|Marineflieger-Geschwader 1]] Eleven months after the F-84 incident, the Soviet threat of to shooting down any aircraft violating the border materialized when a [[Hawker Sea Hawk]] of the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'', piloted by [[Kapitänleutnant]] Knut Anton Winkler, was shot at by [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21|MiG-21]] fighters when it accidentally crossed into East German airspace near [[Eisenach]]. Winkler, who had been returning from a training exercise on board {{USS|Saratoga|CV-60|6}} in the Atlantic Ocean, had to carry out an emergency landing at [[Ahlhorn]], 45 km southwest of [[Bremen]].<ref name="Monat" /> The aircraft was eventually written-off.<ref>[http://home.snafu.de/veith/seahawk.htm DDR-Luftwaffe.de – Sea Hawk] {{de icon}}</ref> Winkler himself died less than four years later in a [[F-104 Starfighter]] accident on 10 May 1966.<ref>[http://www.cactus-starfighter-staffel.de/public/html/in_memoriam.html In Memoriam] List of German pilots killed in F-104 Starfighter accidents, accessed: 2 December 2010</ref>

Records|Warner Bros.]] (US) | writer = Sarah McLachlan | producer = [[Pierre Marchand]] | prev_title = [[Adia]] | prev_year = 1998 | next_title = [[I Will Remember You (Sarah McLachlan song)|I Will Remember You]] | next_year = 1999 | misc = {{Extra music sample | type = single | filename = Angel Sarah McLachlan.ogg | format = [[Ogg]] | title = "Angel" }} }} "'''Angel'''" is a song by Canadian singer-songwriter [[Sarah McLachlan]] about the [[heroin]] [[overdose]] death of [[Jonathan Melvoin]] (1961-1996), the [[Smashing Pumpkins]] touring keyboard player, {{cite web|url=http://www.funtrivia.com/en/music/drugs-in-songs-17801.html|title=Drugs in Songs|publisher=Fun Trivia|accessdate=22 August 2014}} as McLachlan explained on ''[[VH1 Storytellers]]''. The song first appeared on ''[[Surfacing (album)|Surfacing]]'', the Canadian singer's 1997 album. It is sometimes mistitled as '''"In the Arms of an Angel"'''Ebony - Oct 2007 - Page 194 "He decided against killing himself while back in the United States after hearing on the radio Sarah McLachlan's song "In the Arms of an Angel." " and other examples or '''"Arms of the Angel"'''. "Angel" was McLachlan's second consecutive top five hit on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart, debuting at number twelve, and then jumping to the top ten the following week, before peaking at number four. It remained at the top ten for nineteen weeks, and for twenty-nine weeks in the top 100. "Angel" was the eighteenth most successful song of 1999. ==Background== "Angel" was one of the first songs written for ''[[Surfacing (album)|Surfacing]]''. McLachlan said that writing it was easy, "a real joyous occasion", and that "the bulk of it came in about three hours." It was inspired by articles that she read in ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' about musicians turning to [[heroin]] to cope with the pressures of the music industry and subsequently overdosing.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ISHRr29MaFs&t=99 Sarah McLachlan explaining her inspiration to write 'Angel'] (interview discussing Surfacing CD, posted to YouTube on Dec 9, 2008) She said that she identified with the feelings that might lead someone to use heroin: "I've been in that place where you've messed up and you're so lost that you don't know who you are anymore, and you're miserable—and here's this escape route. I've never done heroin, but I've done plenty of other things to escape." She said that the song is about "trying not to take responsibility for other people's problems and trying to love yourself at the same time". ==Release== {{unreferenced section|date=June 2014}} Released as a single in 1998, "Angel" peaked at #4 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] on February 22, 1999 (after reaching the Top 40 on December 15, 1998), #1 on the [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]] chart, and at #36 on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. The song has had enduring popularity. It is often used to highlight emotional scenes on television shows, and has been featured in a number of [[soundtrack]]s (including the film ''[[City of Angels (soundtrack)|City of Angels]]'' and TV's ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', ''[[As the World Turns]]'', ''[[Cold Case]]'', ''[[Dawson's Creek]]'', ''[[Early Edition]]'', ''[[Felicity (TV series)|Felicity]]'', ''[[General Hospital]]'', ''[[Providence (TV series)|Providence]]'', ''[[Strong Medicine]]'', and ''[[The Pretender (TV series)|The Pretender]]''). In addition, it is also used as a song of comfort and healing, most often following tragic events such as the death on [[Diana, Princess of Wales]] in August 1997, the April 1999 [[Columbine High School massacre]] and the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]]. Furthermore, a large number of video tributes to loved ones uploaded by [[YouTube]] users have been set to this song. On July 2, 2005, McLachlan performed this song at [[Live 8 Philadelphia]] with [[Josh Groban]]. She also performed the song during the "[[Concert for Linda]]," dedicating it to the memory of [[Linda McCartney]]. On September 10, 2011, McLachlan performed the song to close the ceremonies at the dedication of the [[Flight 93 Memorial]] in [[Stonycreek Township, Somerset County, Pennsylvania|Stonycreek Township]], commemorating the passengers and crew of [[United Airlines Flight 93]] who fought the hijackers and brought down their airplane in the [[September 11 attacks]]. Musician [[Darryl McDaniels]], otherwise known as D.M.C. of the hip-hop band [[Run-D.M.C.]], has said that the song saved his life.{{cite web|title=DMC: Saved By An Angel - How Sarah McLachlan thwarted the legendary MC's suicidal tendencies.|url=http://music.ign.com/articles/691/691277p1.html|date=2006-02-24|publisher=[[IGN]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025104607/http://music.ign.com/articles/691/691277p1.html|archivedate=2008-10-25|df=}} The song has a sparse arrangement — mostly McLachlan at the piano, with subtle upright bass played by [[Jim Creeggan]] of [[Barenaked Ladies]]. It was recorded in the key of [[D-flat major]].{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0119791|title=Sarah McLachlan "Angel" Sheet Music in Db Major (transposable) - Download & Print|first=McLachlan,|last=Sarah|website=Musicnotes.com|accessdate=4 August 2018}} For live performances, it is transposed up one half-step to [[D major]], the key it was originally written in, and played without the bass. A remix of the track by [[Dusted (British band)|Dusted]] appears on McLachlan's 2001 album ''[[Remixed (Sarah McLachlan album)|Remixed]]''. A live version with [[Emmylou Harris]] appears on a [[Lilith Fair]] compilation, McLachlan's own [[iTunes Originals]] collection, and her ''[[Rarities, B-Sides and Other Stuff Volume 2]]'' compilation. On Sunday, November 23, 2008, Sarah McLachlan performed "Angel" at the [[American Music Awards]] with artist [[Pink (singer)|Pink]]. The song made its début on the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]] on 6 July 2009 at number 36 But Climbed down the charts to number 3 after the success of the City of Angels Movie.Mandy Pickering of [[Christchurch]] won the Stars in there eyes finale performing the song in the Grand Finale. The song is also often played during a contestant becoming eliminated on ''[[Indonesia Mencari Bakat]]'' ([[Indonesia]]n version of ''[[America's Got Talent]]'') on [[Trans TV]]. This song was used in the final minutes of the season finale of season 3 for ''[[The Secret Life of the American Teenager]]'' as everyone discovers that Ben and Adrian's baby is stillborn. The 2009 [[Hallmark Hall of Fame]] movie ''[[A Dog Named Christmas]]'' used this song in one scene. In the 2015 Korean TV Drama [[Yong-pal]] the full Westlife version was used in one of the final scenes of episode 7. ===ASPCA=== Since 2007, "Angel" has been included in an advertisement for the [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] (ASPCA) in which McLachlan serves as the spokesperson. The song is played over video of dogs and cats in an animal shelter and is credited with helping raise millions of dollars for the ASPCA.{{cite web|title=Ad Featuring Singer Proves Bonanza for the A.S.P.C.A.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/26/us/26charity.html|date=2008-12-25|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''}} This ad was later parodied numerous times on the internet and inspired many [[internet meme|memes]]. The song was also donated by McLachlan for Tribe of Heart's movie ''[[The Witness (2000 film)|The Witness]]'' which depicts the awakening of consciousness of a New York City construction worker with respect to the [[treatment of animals]].{{cite web |url=http://www.witnessfilm.org/wt_music1_english.htm |title=Sarah McLachlan, Angel and The Witness |last1=LaVeck |first1=James |last2=Stein |first2=Jenny |publisher=Tribe of Heart |accessdate=2012-12-31}} ==Charts and certifications== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" !scope="col"|Chart (1998–2015) !scope="col"|Peak

The '''Anti-Terrorism Squad''' (ATS) is a special police force in several states of [[India]] including [[Maharashtra]], [[Gujarat]], [[Kerala]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Rajasthan]] and [[Bihar]].<ref name=bp>{{cite web|title=Sarat Kumar appointed as Bihar ATS Chief|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2013/11/paresh-saxena-appointed-as-bihar-ats-chief/|work=Biharprabha News|accessdate=24 November 2013}}</ref> In Maharashtra it is headed by senior IPS officer Vivek Phansalkar <ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2009/06/12/stories/2009061259811400.htm "Maharashtra ATS gets new chief"] [[The Hindu]], 2015</ref> The squad has stopped several terrorist attacks in the country.
ATS was founded in Maharashtra in 1990 by then Additional Commissioner of Mumbai Police [[Aftab Ahmed Khan]] popularly known as A.A. Khan. He was inspired by the [[Los Angeles Police Department]]'s Special Weapons & Tactics ([[SWAT]]) teams methods to combat modern-day terrorism. Since its formation in 1990, ATS's officers have won 23 gallantry awards. The Mumbai ATS was involved in the [[2008 Mumbai attacks|26 November 2008 hostage rescue operations]] in multiple locations in [[Mumbai]], Maharashtra including the 5 star hotels [[The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel|Taj]] and [[Oberoi Trident]]. After the attacks, it also started appointing children (ages above 12) as officers of ATC, particularly in Mumbai, and were given training as undercover.
==Termination and reformation== The ATS was formed on December 1990 and helped reduce the crime rate in Mumbai by 70%. However, there were many human rights violations by the squad, from extreme means of torture to public shootings. Following the [[1991 Lokhandwala Complex shootout]] on 16 November 1991 and many more encounters, the organization was terminated in January 1993. The leader of this program, A.A. Khan, was transferred as the ICP Anti Naxalite division to [[Nagpur]] on 29 January 1993 following the termination of the program. One month later on 12 March 1993 the [[1993 Bombay bombings|Bombay blasts]] occurred, and the crime rate has increased since then.
As per the information available on the official website of Mumbai Police, ATS was created by the Government of Maharashtra, vide G.R. No. SAS-10/03/15/SB-IV, dated 8 July 2004<ref name="MUMATS">[http://www.mumbaipolice.org/special/anit_terror_squad.htm "ANTI - TERRORISM SQUAD"] mumbaipolice.org retrieved on 27 July 2009</ref> The stated objectives of ATS are:
# To gain information about anti-national elements working in any part of Maharashtra # To co-ordinate with central information agencies like the [[Intelligence Bureau (India)|IB]] and [[Research & Analysis Wing|RAW]] and exchange information with them # To co-ordinate with similar agencies of other states # To track and eliminate activities of mafia and other organized crime syndicates # To detect rackets of counterfeit currency notes and smuggling narcotic substances<ref name="MUMATS" />
==Branches== Several states in India have created ATS units in their respective police forces, including : *[[Maharashtra]] *[[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Leena Misra |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2003-07-22/ahmedabad/27200264_1_anti-terror-cells-islamic-fundamentalism-gujarat-police |title=ATS to branch out to other cities in state - Ahmedabad - City - The Times of India |publisher=The Times of India |date=2003-07-22 |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> *[[Lucknow]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *[[Kerala]] *[[Rajasthan]] *[[Bihar]] *[[Madhya Pradesh]] *[[West Bengal]]
==1991 shootout at Lokhandwala== On 16 November 1991 the ATS Chief, A.A. Khan, lead a squad of officers into the Swati building in [[Lokhandwala]], eliminating 7 gangsters including [[Maya Dolas]] and [[Dilip Buwa]]. The shootout lasted 4 hours and more than 450 rounds were fired.
==November 2008 Mumbai attacks== The former ATS Chief [[Hemant Karkare]] was killed [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks|fighting terrorists]] on 26 November 2008, at the [[Cama Hospital|Cama & Albless Hospital]] in the [[Dhobitalao]] area of Mumbai. Karkare was killed with other two officers: Additional Commissioner [[Ashok Kamte]] and [[Encounter killings|encounter specialist]] [[Vijay Salaskar]]. He was among the 14 police officials killed while fighting terrorists in Mumbai.
The terrorists had holed up in many heritage locations of Mumbai, such as the [[The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel|Taj Mahal Palace Hotel]] and [[Oberoi Trident|the Oberoi]] and [[Oberoi Trident|Trident, Nariman Point]] hotels. Here the terrorists had killed 146 people, wounded at least 327, and taken at least 15 people hostage. Indians accounted for 96 dead of those, and at least 300 of those injured.
Karkare, a 1982 batch IPS officer, had returned to his state cadre after a seven-year tenure with the [[Research and Analysis Wing]], India's external intelligence agency, in Austria.
==2009 shootout== On 25 January 2009, after receiving a tip-off, ATS agents chased a [[Maruti 800]] car bearing a '[[Uttar Pradesh|UP]]' number-plate in [[Noida]]. During the chase, the terrorists shot at the police officers who retaliated, causing the car to hit the rear tyre of the suspects' car, veering it off the road. ATS officers then took cover behind a roadblock and engaged the terrorists for 38 minutes in a fierce gun-battle. Officer Vinod Kumar sustained a bullet injury during the gunfight. The two terrorists ceased firing after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds and succumbed to their injuries while they were rushed to the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/videoshow/4029172.cms |title=Two alleged terrorists shot dead in Noida-News-Videos-The Times of India |publisher=The Times of India |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-01-25/india/28008871_1_ats-noida-police-car |title=Two suspected Pak terrorists shot dead in Noida - India - The Times of India |publisher=The Times of India |date=2009-01-25 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref>

In October 2008, '''Ashley Todd''', a volunteer for the [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|U.S. presidential campaign]] of [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[John McCain]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/us_politics/view.bg?articleid=1127679&srvc=2008campnews&position=2|title=John McCain volunteer admits mugging story is lie|date=October 25, 2008|work=[[Boston Herald]]|accessdate=2011-05-12}}</ref> falsely claimed to have been the victim of [[robbery]] and politically motivated [[physical assault]] by a supporter of McCain's [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] opponent [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news |title=McCain Campaign Volunteer Admits Alleged Attack Was a Hoax |url=http://elections.foxnews.com/2008/10/24/mccain-campaign-volunteer-admits-alleged-attack-hoax/ |work=[[Fox News]] |date=October 24, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref> The story broke less than two weeks before the 2008 [[United States presidential election, 2008|United States presidential election]] on November 4. Todd later confessed to inventing the story after surveillance photos and a [[Polygraph|polygraph test]] were presented. She was charged with filing a false police report, and entered a probation program for first-time offenders.
==Initial claim and political commentary== Todd had worked as a field representative for the [[College Republican National Committee]] since August 2008 and had come to [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] in mid-October to recruit college students.<ref name="ppg"> {{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08299/922849-53.stm |title=McCain volunteer admits to hoax |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |accessdate=2008-10-31 |last=Fuoco |first=Michael A. | date=October 25, 2008 }}</ref> On October 22, 2008, Todd claimed that she was robbed at knifepoint by a "six-foot-four [[African American]] of medium build, dressed in dark clothes wearing shiny shoes" at a Citizens Bank [[Automated teller machine|ATM]] in the [[Bloomfield (Pittsburgh)|Bloomfield]] neighborhood of Pittsburgh. She also alleged that after the robber saw a McCain [[bumper sticker]] on Todd's car, he assaulted her, cut a reversed letter ''B'' into her cheek,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kdka.com/video/?id=47866@kdka.dayport.com |title=Mugger Attacked Campaign Volunteer In Pittsburgh |publisher=KDKA Online |accessdate=2008-10-23 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025075412/http://kdka.com/video?id=47866%40kdka.dayport.com |archivedate=October 25, 2008 }} </ref> and told her "you are going to be a Barack supporter."<ref>{{cite news |first=Hannah |last=Strange |title=Republican volunteer charged over false claim of mutilation by Obama supporter |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/us_elections/article5010471.ece |work=Times Online |pages= |date=October 25, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-25 | location=London}}</ref>
Todd's story received international attention, including prominent coverage on [[Drudge Report]] and [[Fox News]]. [[John Moody (journalist)|John Moody]], executive vice president at Fox News, commented in a [[blog]] on the network's website that "this incident could become a watershed event in the 11 days before the election," but also warned that "[i]f the incident turns out to be a hoax, Senator McCain's quest for the presidency is over, forever linked to [[race-baiting]]."<ref>{{cite news|last=Moody |first=John |url=http://foxforum.blogs.foxnews.com/2008/10/23/jmoody_1023/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029224415/http://foxforum.blogs.foxnews.com/2008/10/23/jmoody_1023 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=2008-10-29 |work=Fox News |title=Moment of Truth |date=October 23, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Hoax exposure== On October 24, Todd confessed to inventing the story after police reviewed [[surveillance camera]] photos and administered a [[polygraph]] test.<ref name=KDKA2>{{cite web|url=http://kdka.com/local/attack.McCain.Bloomfield.2.847628.html |title=Police: Campaign Worker Admits Making Up Story |publisher=KDKA Online |accessdate=2008-10-23 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025073658/http://kdka.com/local/attack.McCain.Bloomfield.2.847628.html |archivedate=October 25, 2008 }}</ref> She now said that she had seen the backwards 'B' on her face while driving, and though she did not remember how she got it, assumed that she herself had done it because she had had previous episodes of [[memory loss]].<ref name="ppg" /> According to police, Todd provided no explanation of why she provided them the story about the mugging instead.<ref name="MSNBC">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27456042/ |title=McCain worker reaches deal in hoax assault |work=MSNBC |date=October 30, 2008}}</ref>
Todd was charged with filing a false police report, a [[misdemeanor]] charge with a maximum [[jail sentence]] of two years. While jailed, Todd underwent a court-ordered psychiatric examination and was deemed to be competent to stand trial, but in need of further counseling. On October 30, she agreed to a deal in which she was released from jail, but must undergo [[psychiatric counseling]] as condition of her release. Upon her formal [[arraignment]] in January, Todd would enter a [[probation]] program for first-time offenders, after which her record would be expunged if there had been no further offenses. Continued mental health counseling would also be a condition of the probation period. The deal did not require Todd to enter a [[plea]].<ref name="MSNBC" />
==Prior claim by Todd== According to an October 25, 2008 article in the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'', in February 2008, Todd had claimed that her car's tires had been slashed and campaign material had been stolen from her car because of her support for Republican politician [[Ron Paul]], an opponent of McCain for the Republican presidential nomination. Group leader Dustan Costine told the ''Post-Gazette'' that Todd was asked to leave the local Ron Paul grassroots group a month later, after she posed as a [[Mike Huckabee]] supporter and called the local Republican committee seeking information about its campaign strategies.<ref name="ppg"/>

{{Flagicon|Kabyle}} 90-126 killed (2001)Jonathan Oakes. ''Algeria''. p112. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Vyg7ViBs4JAC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112&dq=algeria+berber+killed&source=bl&ots=kmHvuZXvAP&sig=ndA8oCbzPsNpvsMt8-PZZJpSgdk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj49Kyis6nUAhXEuxQKHV-nA9A4ChDoAQgnMAE#v=onepage&q=algeria%20berber%20killed&f=false] |casualties3 = }} {{Campaignbox Berber separatism in North Africa}} '''Berber separatism in North Africa''' refers to a century-long independence struggle of ethnic [[Berbers|Berber]] groups in the areas of modern [[Morocco]], [[Algeria]], [[Mali]] and [[Libya]]. The first chapter of this modern separatism was embodied in the [[Rif War]],[https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs4uw9Uw1C0C&pg=PA46 White Gypsies: Race and Stardom in Spanish Musical Films - Eva Woods Peiró]. p. 46.[https://books.google.com/books?id=eSWDAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Rif+Independence+Movement%22&dq=%22Rif+Independence+Movement%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0PFlU6L_O8O-oQTlkIG4Dw&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg What the Arabs think - William Roe Polk]. p. 52. which led to the creation of short-lived [[Rif Republic]] (1920–1926). Despite the disintegration of this Berber state, the independence movement continued during the 20th century in Algeria and in 21st century was led by [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] tribes in Mali and Libya (the failed attempt to form the [[Azawad]] state within Mali in 2012 and ''de facto'' formation of [[Tuareg militias of Ghat|Tuareg autonomy of Ghat]] within Libya since 2014), and last resurging in Morocco in 2013,{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/155144338/The-Rif-Independence-Movement-Joins-OEAS|title=The Rif Independence Movement Joins OEAS|website=Scribd}} escalating into a Berber protest movement in 2016–17. ==Timeline== ===Rif War=== The [[Rif War]] was an armed conflict fought during the first half of the 1920s between the colonial power [[History of Spain|Spain]] (later joined by [[History of France|France]]) and the [[Berber people|Berber]] tribes of the [[Rif]] mountainous region. Led by [[Abd el-Krim|Abd al-Karim]], the Riffians at first inflicted several defeats on the Spanish forces by using [[guerrilla tactics]] and captured European weapons. After France's entry into the conflict and the major landing of Spanish troops at [[Alhucemas landing|Al Hoceima]], considered the first amphibious landing in history to involve the use of [[tank]]s and [[aircraft]], Abd el-Karim surrendered to the French and was taken into exile.Douglas Porch, "Spain's African Nightmare," ''MHQ: Quarterly Journal of Military History'' (2006) 18#2 pp 28–37. The nature of the Rif War is still controversial among historians today. Some see in it a harbinger of the decolonization process in North Africa, while others, on the contrary, see it as one of the last colonial wars, given that it is the decision of the Spaniards to conquer the Rif — nominally part of their Moroccan protectorate but still independent de facto — that launched the conflict in 1921.[https://www.cairn.info/revue-strategique-2009-1-page-319.htm Jan Pascal, ''L’Armée française face à Abdelkrim ou la tentation de mener une guerre conventionnelle dans une guerre irrégulière 1924-1927''], Cairn.Info, 2009, p. 732. ===1958 Rif disturbances=== In 1958, Moroccan King Hassan II ordered thousands of troops to the Rif region to quell a civil disobedience movement that had called for social and political rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/interactive/2017/06/morocco-fuelling-unrest-rif-170601141849532.html|title=Morocco: What is fuelling unrest in the Rif?|website=www.aljazeera.com}} As a result, many left the Rif for Europe in search of a better life, returning to their ancestral towns only to build homes that they lived in during vacations or after retirement. This, along with the diversion of much of the region's arable land for cannabis planting, has decimated the local economy and environment. ===Kabylie movement=== ====Berber Spring (1980)==== The [[Berber Spring]] was a period of political protest and civil activism in 1980 claiming recognition of the [[Berber people|Berber]] identity and language in [[Algeria]], with events mainly taking place in [[Kabylie]] and [[Algiers]]. The background was marked by two decades of harsh [[Arabization]] measures instituted by the [[Arab nationalist]] [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|FLN]] dictatorship government, which refused to recognize Algeria's Berber identity and banned the [[Berber language]] altogether. The Berber Spring is traditionally dated as beginning on March 10, 1980, with the banning of a conference due to be held by the Kabyle intellectual [[Mouloud Mammeri]] at Hasnaoua University in [[Tizi-Ouzou]]. A critical point was the coordinated arrest of hundreds of Berber activists, students and doctors on April 20, sparking a [[general strike]]. While the Berber Spring was in the end violently suppressed by the Algerian authorities, it created a lasting legacy for Kabylie and the Berbers across North Africa. Many of today's prominent Kabyle politicians and activists made their name during the Berber Spring events, and organizations such as the [[Rally for Culture and Democracy]] (RCD) and the Berber Cultural Movement (Mouvement Culturel Berbère – MCB) were later created by activists of the Spring. The Spring was also an important event for Algeria's nascent human rights community, including outside Berber circles. Since the dismantling of the one-party FLN system in 1989—followed by abortive [[democratization]] and [[Algerian Civil War|civil war]]—a few of the demands of the Berber Spring have been met by the state, and the Berber language is now a [[national language]] of Algeria. However, this is still distinct from [[Arabic]], which remains the [[official language]], and many other points of contention remain. ====2014–15 ethnic clashes==== In 2014 and 2015 a number of ethnic riot incidents plagued Algeria, with a dozen mortal casualties in violence between ethnic Arabs and Berbers. ====2017 protests==== In February 2017, protests erupted in Algeria, with some 500 protesters marching.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-algeria-protest-idUSTRE71I15U20110219|title=Hundreds of protesters defy police in Algeria|date=19 February 2011|publisher=|via=Reuters}} The protest was organized by human rights groups, some trade unionists and a small opposition party. Algeria's main opposition forces were not taking part. Large numbers of police had been mobilized to try to prevent the protest from going ahead. Police at the protest detained Belaid Abrika, a prominent opposition figure and campaigner for the rights of Algeria's large Berber minority. ===Azawad=== ===Libyan Civil War=== ===Berber protests in Morocco=== Since 2013 the Rif Independence Movement resurged in Morocco. Rif Independence Movement is a charter member of the Organization of Emerging African States. Since late 2016, massive riots have spread across Moroccan Berber communities in the Rif region, initiated after a death of a fishmonger in Al-Hoceima in October 2016. On 31 October, massive demonstrations took place across Morocco, staged by the Berber minority.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/31/morocco-protests-after-fisherman-crushed-to-death-in-a-garbage-truck|title=Morocco protests after fisherman crushed to death in a garbage truck|first=Associated|last=Press|date=31 October 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} During January and February 2017, the riots intensified and were marked by unemployment concerns, with around thirty police officers injured in the north Moroccan town of al-Hoceima, after tear gas and rubber bullets were deployed against thousands of mostly young protesters.{{cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/2/7/berber-nationalist-protests-break-out-in-al-hoceima-north-morocco|title=Berber nationalist protests break out in al-Hoceima, north Morocco|first=Robert|last=Cusack|publisher=}} Another escalation took place in May 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/morocco-police-hunt-rif-region-protest-leader-170527140125639.html|title=Morocco police hunt Rif region protest leader|website=www.aljazeera.com}} The protests were led by Nasser Zefzafi, founder of the Al-Hirak al-Shaabi, or the Popular Movement.{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/morocco-protests-2017-nasser-zefzafi-618731|title=“We are all Zefzafi”—who is the Morocco protest leader causing problems for the king?|date=2017-06-01|work=Newsweek|access-date=2017-06-06|language=en}} Zefzafi was arrested by Moroccan Police in late May 2017. Thousands took to the streets in Al-Hoceima since Zefzafi’s arrest, and demonstrations have also spread to the capital Rabat and Casablanca. Demonstrators proclaimed “We are all Zefzafi” and waved Berber flags, with around 40 people arrested. By 30 May, the number of arrested protesters reached 70.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/scores-arrested-connection-morocco-rif-protests-170530184329431.html|title=Scores arrested in connection with Morocco Rif protests|website=www.aljazeera.com}} ==See also== {{portal|Berbers|Arab World|Africa}} * [[Berbers]] * [[List of modern conflicts in North Africa]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{ongoing military conflicts}} [[Category:Berber]] [[Category:Berberism]] [[Category:Rebellions in Morocco]] [[Category:Wars involving Morocco]] [[Category:Rebellions in Algeria]] [[Category:History of North Africa]] [[Category:Wars involving Algeria]] [[Category:Rebellions in Mali]] [[Category:Wars involving Mali]] [[Category:Rebellions in Libya]] [[Category:Wars involving Libya]] [[Category:Berber separatism in North Africa]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Opposition to Arab nationalism]]

'''Bhumchu''' (Bhum is a pot, Chum is water) is a [[Buddhist]] festival, which on the Tibetan lunar calendar is held on the 14th and 15th day of the first month, which is between February and March on the [[Gregorian calendar]].<ref>http://traditionscustoms.com/festivals/bhumchu-festival</ref> The Bhum or Sacred vase, according to Zigpo Lingpa, is made out of various kinds of sacred soil, water and five kinds of precious jewels found in sacred lands of [[India]], Odiyana and Zahor. In [[Sikkim]] the [[Tashiding Monastery]] is recognized as a sacred place. It is believed that this place, Dakkar Tashiding in the center of four sacred caves, Sharchog Bephug in the east, Khandozangphu in the south, Dechenphug in the west and Lhari Nyingphug in the north, is meant to free you from the suffering of hell. At the start of the year the vase is opened and the Lama or monk determines the future. “If the water is to the brim, it foretells a year in which peace and prosperity will prevail. If the water is over the brim and is spilling, it signifies a year with natural disaster and disturbances. If the water level is low or almost dry it signifies famine.” The celebration of “The Holy Water Vase” started under the rule of [[Trisong Deutson|King Trisong Deutsonin]] Tibet, [[Padmasambhava|Guru Padmasambhava]].” It is believed that the water overflowed from the vase as a sign of a good omen and there was an earthquake. The four guardian deities of Dharma and the gods of thirty three heavens showered flowers from the sky.” This ritual is one of the holiest in Sikkim. From midnight until the next day thousands are seen waiting to receive the holy water. “A part of the holy water is distributed amongst the gathering of devotes and the pot is replenished with river water and sealed at the end of the festival to be opened only in the during next Bumchu festival.” It is said that by taking a drop of the Bumchu water enlightenment is achieved and all of the evil spirits and distress are removed. It is said one would somehow attain a form of Buddhahood or be born at a higher ranking in the next life. In 2016, it will be on March 19-20.<ref>http://www.travel-sikkim.com/event/Bhumchu</ref>

{{Infobox Historic Site | name = Brighton Hippodrome | image = Former Brighton Hippodrome, Middle Street, Brighton (IoE Code 482157).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = The façade of the Brighton Hippodrome from the northwest | locmapin = United Kingdom Brighton | map_caption = Location within central Brighton | coordinates = {{coord|50.8218|-0.1427|region:GB_type:landmark|format=dec|display=inline,title}} | location = 52–58 Middle Street, [[Brighton]], [[Brighton and Hove]], [[East Sussex]], [[United Kingdom]] | built = 1897 | rebuilt = 1901; 1939 | architect = [[Frank Matcham]] (1901) | architecture = | designation1 = Grade II* | designation1_offname = Mecca Bingo (Former Hippodrome), 52–58 Middle Street | designation1_date = 20 December 1985 | designation1_number = 1381793 }} '''Brighton Hippodrome''' is an entertainment venue in the ancient centre of [[Brighton]], part of the English city of [[Brighton and Hove]]. It has been empty and out of use since 2007, when its use as a [[Bingo (Commonwealth)|bingo hall]] ceased.
From its construction in 1897 it has hosted an ice rink, circus acts, [[Variety show|variety theatre]], [[vaudeville]] shows and bands such as [[The Beatles]] and [[The Rolling Stones]]. The flamboyantly decorated interior, with a large auditorium and [[Rococo]] embellishments, survives despite the frequent alterations; but in July 2010 its owner announced that it would cost £9 million to restore the building and convert it into a live music venue, and a [[charitable trust]] expressed concern over its future. Since 2011, several plans have been submitted to convert the building for alternative uses. [[English Heritage]] has [[Listed building|listed]] the building at Grade II* for its architectural and historical importance.
==History== By the end of the 19th century, Brighton had been a fashionable and thriving [[seaside resort]], which had experienced rapid growth, for more than 100 years. It developed around the medieval fishing village of Brighthelmstone—a grid of streets running inland from the sea, intercut with narrow [[Alley|twittens]]. Middle Street, the most important and central of these streets, was built up from the 16th century, and was lined with houses both large and small, inns, the town's oldest school and a [[Middle Street Synagogue, Brighton|richly decorated synagogue]].<ref name="Antram75">{{Harvnb|Antram|Morrice|2008|p=75.}}</ref><ref name="NEB173">{{Harvnb|Collis|2010|p=173.}}</ref><ref name="HAoB14–15">{{Harvnb|Dale|1950|pp=14–15.}}</ref>
Land on the east side of the street was chosen as the site of the Real Ice Skating Rink in 1897. It was designed by the architect Lewis Karslake and had a long [[stucco]]ed façade with short towers at each end.<ref name="Antram77">{{Harvnb|Antram|Morrice|2008|p=77.}}</ref> The venture was unsuccessful, as ice-skating did not gain popularity; and in 1900, the owners converted the venue into a circus. [[Frank Matcham]], a prolific theatre architect, was engaged to enlarge and rebuild the interior.<ref name="BoB39">{{Harvnb|Brighton Polytechnic. School of Architecture and Interior Design|1987|p=39.}}</ref> The building was renamed ''The Hippodrome'' and reopened in its new form in 1901. The following year the circus failed and the site was auctioned. It was bought by theatre entrepreneur [[Thomas Barrasford]]<ref name="ODNB">{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/56527|title=Oxford DNB article: Barrasford, Thomas|last=Russell|first=Dave|year=2004|work=[[Dictionary of National Biography#Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/56527|accessdate=1 December 2010}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> who modified the auditorium, replacing the circus ring with seating, and on 22 December 1902 the Hippodrome reopened as a [[Variety show|variety theatre]].<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NEB335">{{Harvnb|Collis|2010|p=335.}}</ref>
Barrasford died at the venue in February 1910 and the Hippodrome was sold to the Variety Theatres Controlling Company (VTCC). It quickly became Brighton's most important variety theatre.<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="Musgrave311"/> Shows of all types were staged there, and top-name entertainers such as [[Harry Houdini]], [[W C Fields]], [[Lillie Langtry]], [[Sarah Bernhardt]], [[Gracie Fields]], [[Laurel and Hardy]] and [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]] appeared.<ref name="BoB39"/><ref name="Argus-8624311">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/yesterdays/past_present/8624311.Home_of_the_stars/ |title=Home of the stars |last=Trimingham |first=Adam |date=8 November 2010 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaU24tB?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/yesterdays/past_present/8624311.Home_of_the_stars/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Laurence Olivier]] made his professional stage début—but fell over on his first entrance.<ref name="BoB39"/> One of [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s first roles was a bit-part in theatre impresario [[Fred Karno]]'s comedy ''Saturday to Monday'', staged in May 1907;<ref name="Musgrave359">{{Harvnb|Musgrave|1981|p=359.}}</ref> and [[Vivien Leigh]] gave an acclaimed performance in [[George Bernard Shaw]]'s play ''[[The Doctor's Dilemma (play)|The Doctor's Dilemma]]'' in January 1942.<ref name="Musgrave311">{{Harvnb|Musgrave|1981|p=311.}}</ref> Local stars also featured: [[Max Miller (comedian)|Max Miller]], the Brighton-born [[music hall]] entertainer and comedian, appeared on many occasions between 1928 and 1960;<ref name="NEB335"/> and [[conjoined twins]] [[Daisy and Violet Hilton]], whose [[vaudeville]] career began in their home town in 1911 at the age of three, topped the bill with their variety show.<ref name="NEB148">{{Harvnb|Collis|2010|p=148.}}</ref>
The venue's early success led to expansion. In 1919 the lower floors of the two houses on the north side,<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793">{{NHLE|num=1381793|desc=Mecca Bingo, Nos. 52–58 (consecutive) Middle Street (east side), Brighton, Brighton and Hove, East Sussex|grade=II*|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> known as Hippodrome House since Barrasford made his home there in 1902, was converted into a Palm Court for teas and dances. Its maximum capacity may have been up to 3,000 although an attendance of 4,500 was recorded on one occasion.<ref name="Argus-8624311"/> Further changes of ownership in 1928 and 1932 made the Hippodrome part of the [[Moss Empires]] circuit.
After World War II, the popularity of variety theatre waned,<ref name="NEB335"/> and the new practice of centralised booking of productions by an agency in London meant that the tastes of Brighton audiences were not specifically catered for: the venue typically received shows that had toured around the country and had no local connection.<ref name="Musgrave311"/> The Hippodrome accordingly hosted concerts and other large-scale events: concerts by [[The Beatles]] (part of their [[The Beatles' 1964 world tour|1964 World Tour]]) and [[The Rolling Stones]] (on their [[The Rolling Stones 4th British Tour 1964|4th British Tour 1964]]) in October 1964.<ref name="NEB335"/> This could not stop the decline, though, and on 22 November 1964 the theatre was closed. Brighton Corporation considered acquisition but the idea lapsed. In 1966 it was converted into a short-lived television and film studio.<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="Musgrave311"/> In 1967, it was turned into a [[The Rank Group#Mecca Bingo|Mecca Bingo]] hall;<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="Musgrave311"/> the conversion work included the insertion of a raised floor above the stage and through the [[proscenium]] arch.<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> Mecca was bought by the [[Rank Organisation]] in 1990.
[[File:Former Hippodrome, Brighton (Glazed Awning over Entrance).jpg|thumb|left|The glazed awning spans the façade. The three-arched main entrance is visible below this section.]] Repairs were carried out on the coloured glass awnings above the entrance in the early 1990s.<ref name="Antram77"/> The building closed as a bingo hall in August 2006 and is still empty as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}.<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="Argus-8624311"/> In 2003, property investment firm London Merchant Securities (later called Cheval Properties) bought it and leased it to [[Academy Music Group]] (AMG), who planned to work with events company [[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation]] to establish a live music venue in it.<ref name="NEB335"/><ref name="Argus-8278223">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/8278223.Brighton_Hippodrome_on_danger_list/ |title=Brighton Hippodrome on danger list |last=Loomes |first=Naomi |date=17 July 2010 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaU43BJ?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/8278223.Brighton_Hippodrome_on_danger_list/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In July 2010, AMG announced that this would probably cost at least £9 million: suitable soundproofing in the narrow, partly residential street would cost about £3 million, and the deteriorating structural condition meant repair work would be difficult and expensive. Initial analysis work cost £{{frac|1|2}} million.<ref name="Argus-8278223"/><ref name="BHBF">{{cite web|url=http://www.brightonbusiness.co.uk/htm/ni20100718.126101.htm |title=Hippodrome refurbishment bill could be over £9m |date=18 July 2010 |publisher=Brighton & Hove Business Forum |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaU5oG6?url=http://www.brightonbusiness.co.uk/htm/ni20100718.126101.htm |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The [[Theatres Trust]], the statutory advisory body on theatre conservation, placed the Hippodrome on its register of "buildings requiring special attention"<ref name="Argus-8278223"/> in 2009; on a list of 82 theatres in Britain, it was placed in the top ten at highest risk.<ref name="TTT">{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/894-four-sites-join-theatre-at-risk-list |title=Four sites join theatre "at risk" list |date=24 June 2009 |publisher=The Theatres Trust |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaU8Ode?url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/894-four-sites-join-theatre-at-risk-list |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> It was number one on the list in 2013 and the following three years.<ref name="TTT2">{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/6438-unique-circus-theatre-brighton-hippodrome-tops-theatre-buildings-at-risk-register-2014|title=Unique circus theatre, Brighton Hippodrome, tops Theatre Buildings at Risk Register 2014|date=18 September 2009|publisher=The Theatres Trust|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>
[[Brighton and Hove City Council]] stated in October 2011 that AMG had met officers from the licensing and planning departments in an attempt to move the situation forward.<ref name="Argus-9283052">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/9283052.Talks_on_plans_to_re_open_Brighton_Hippodrome/ |title=Talks on plans to re-open Brighton Hippodrome |last=Ridgway |first=Tim |date=3 October 2011 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaU9vqM?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/9283052.Talks_on_plans_to_re_open_Brighton_Hippodrome/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Four months later, Live Nation announced its intention to seek [[planning permission]] to convert the building into "one of the city’s main live music venues", at an estimated cost of £9 million. By this time the company had spent at least £100,000 on structural and other surveys.<ref name="Argus-9553655">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/9553655.Brighton_Hippodrome_restoration_moves_closer/ |title=Brighton Hippodrome restoration moves closer |last=Evans |first=Rebecca |date=25 February 2012 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaUCRXJ?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/9553655.Brighton_Hippodrome_restoration_moves_closer/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Nothing came of these plans, though, and in February 2013 another group—Alaska Development Consultants—unveiled an £18 million plan to turn the Hippodrome into an eight-screen cinema. Five new shops and a public square would be part of the plans, and the building would be connected to an adjacent shopping arcade. Local firm Russ Drage Architects drew up the plans.<ref name="Argus-10369705">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/10369705.Brighton_Hippodrome_to_become_a_cinema/ |title=Brighton Hippodrome to become a cinema |last=Ridgway |first=Tim |date=21 April 2013 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaUFSX8?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/10369705.Brighton_Hippodrome_to_become_a_cinema/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> A local and national campaign, preferring the building to be used for live theatre or similar events, protested against the plans; but by January 2014 Alaska Development Consultants' proposals had evolved into a £35 million scheme including a restaurant on a removable floor above the auditorium.<ref name="Argus-10934552">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/10934552.__35m_scheme_for_historic_Hippodrome_theatre_in_Brighton_unveiled/ |title=£35m scheme for historic Hippodrome theatre in Brighton unveiled |date=14 January 2014 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaUHYfN?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/10934552.__35m_scheme_for_historic_Hippodrome_theatre_in_Brighton_unveiled/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[English Heritage]] announced their support for these plans in April 2014,<ref name="Argus-11134457">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/11134457.Controversial_Brighton_Hippodrome_cinema_plans_get_English_Heritage_backing/ |title=Controversial Brighton Hippodrome cinema plans get English Heritage backing |date=9 April 2014 |work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]] |accessdate=27 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeaUKMAX?url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/11134457.Controversial_Brighton_Hippodrome_cinema_plans_get_English_Heritage_backing/ |archivedate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and in November 2014 the city council's planning department gave final approval.<ref name="Argus-11344869">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/11344869.Historic_Brighton_theatre_set_to_become_eight_screen_cinema_complex/|title=Historic Brighton Hippodrome is set to become an eight screen cinema complex following city council planners approval|date=16 July 2014|last=Vowles|first=Neil|work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]]|publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media Group]]|accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> The site, together with the contiguous Dukes Lane shopping street, was immediately put on the market. In April 2015, AMG acquired the freehold and offered campaigners a six-month moratorium to develop plans for restoration.<ref>https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/brighton-hippodrome-ripe-to-become-a-theatre-of-varieties-report-concludes/</ref> Work to achieve restoration continues.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/oct/29/lost-empires-battle-save-seaside-theatres</ref>
Under the name ''Mecca Bingo, 52–58 Middle Street'', the building was [[Listed building|listed]] at Grade II* on 20 December 1985;<ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> such buildings are defined as being "particularly important ... [and] of more than special interest".<ref name="EH2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/caring/listing/listed-buildings/ |title=Listed Buildings |year=2012 |publisher=[[English Heritage]] |accessdate=24 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Dus2kPHo?url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/caring/listing/listed-buildings/ |archivedate=24 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> As of February 2001, it was one of [[Grade II* listed buildings in Brighton and Hove|70 Grade II*-listed buildings and structures]], and 1,218 listed buildings of all grades, in the city of [[Brighton and Hove]].<ref name="IoEStats-ESx">{{cite web|title=Images of England — Statistics by County (East Sussex) |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/StatisticsPage/default.aspx?StatsCounty=EAST%20SUSSEX |work=[[Images of England]] |publisher=[[English Heritage]] |year=2007 |accessdate=27 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DEanhkvP?url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/StatisticsPage/default.aspx?StatsCounty=EAST%20SUSSEX |archivedate=27 December 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Architecture== [[File:Former Hippodrome, Brighton (Cartouche with Putti).jpg|thumb|right|Elaborate scrollwork and [[Putto|putti]] decorate the [[Cartouche (design)|cartouches]] above the outer entrances.]] The exterior of the former Hippodrome is in three parts and is [[stucco]]ed, but there is apparently brickwork, [[terracotta]] and stone underneath. The original (1897) section is symmetrical, but the extension northwards in 1939 took in two houses which make the composition unbalanced.<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> The central section has a stepped [[pediment]] above a [[dentil]] cornice and a rectangular panel with the letters {{smallcaps|hippodrome}} projecting. Below this, a three-part awning projects as a [[lean-to]], forming a low roof.<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> This obscures the centre [[Bay (architecture)|bay]], which has three arches with entrances below. The middle entrance has a porch flanked by [[Fluting (architecture)|fluted]] [[pilaster]]s and topped by an [[entablature]] with a pulvinated (convex) [[frieze]]. The arch has a decorative [[archivolt]].<ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> Between the porch and the two plain outer entrances in the centre bay are single straight-headed windows divided into two lights by a single [[mullion]].<ref name="NHLE-1381793"/>
A pair of short towers stand alongside the centre bay. They each have a simple straight-headed entrance with pilasters, a [[cornice]] and a [[pediment]] at ground-floor level, and two more windows and a door above. A wide dentil cornice runs around each tower, and on the inside an extra section projects inwards and upwards beyond the cornice line. Elaborate single-storey entrance bays flank the towers, with [[chamfer]]ed arches, ornate [[Molding (decorative)|mouldings]], [[Ionic order|Ionic columns]] and a [[cornice]]. Above the frieze is a scroll-moulded [[Cartouche (design)|cartouche]] which is framed by the upper sections of the columns.<ref name="NHLE-1381793"/>
Inside, much of Frank Matcham's original work remains, and the design is considered to be one of his finest<ref name="BoB39"/> and to display "his hallmark decorative richness".<ref name="Antram77"/> A narrow foyer leads to an [[auditorium]] shaped like a horseshoe, with seats arranged in a circle around it and in front of the stage. Above this is a [[proscenium]] arch featuring elaborate [[Rococo]]-style moulded plasterwork showing dolphins and female figures, and with [[egg-and-dart]] decoration to the [[architrave]].<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> Above the auditorium is an intricately patterned dome,<ref name="BoB39"/> and there are [[Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture|Indo-Saracenic-style]] [[onion dome]]s on top of the two-part stage-boxes—evoking the style of the nearby [[Royal Pavilion]].<ref name="Antram77"/><ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> The stage and proscenium arch are now partly obscured by the new floor inserted in 1967.<ref name="Antram77"/> More Rococo decoration is found on the panelled segmented ceiling, from which a large lantern also hangs.<ref name="NHLE-1381793"/> The newer rooms on the northern side, all decorated in an elaborate Middle Eastern style, include a conservatory and bars.<ref name="Antram77"/>

[[File:Cern ritual.jpg|thumb|Frame from the video depicting men in cloaks gathered around the statue of Shiva]] The '''CERN ritual''' is a video that depicts an alleged occult ritual occurring in the grounds of [[CERN]], a European particle physics research organization. The video shows several people dressed in black cloaks surrounding a statue of the Hindu deity [[Shiva]] and apparently stabbing a woman in a mock human sacrifice. The video ended with the person filming crying out and running away.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/18/fake-human-sacrifice-filmed-at-cern-with-pranking-scientists-suspected|title=Fake human sacrifice filmed at Cern, with pranking scientists suspected|last=Staff and agencies in Geneva|date=2016-08-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref>
The video went viral in August 2016 in mockery of the many [[conspiracy theories]] concerning CERN. CERN later stated in its FAQ that the video was "fiction" and the actions violated its professional guidelines, as would indeed a real ritual sacrifice.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/cern-devil-worship-sacrifice-video_us_57b6856ce4b00d9c3a16cd67|title=Video Of 'Satanic Ritual' At World's Most Famous Physics Lab Is A Hoax|last=Mazza|first=Ed|date=2016-08-19|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Reactions == A CERN spokesperson stated that the video was a hoax and that no one was actually harmed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.popularmechanics.com/science/a22429/cern-human-sacrifice-prank/|title=CERN Scientists Under Investigation After Fake Human Sacrifice|date=2016-08-18|work=Popular Mechanics|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en-US}}</ref> The enactment was performed without any official permission. CERN stated that it "doesn't tolerate this kind of spoof" and that it can "give rise to misunderstandings about the scientific nature of our work”.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/cern-human-sacrifice-video-watch-hadron-collider-god-particle-a7196881.html|title=Video shows ‘human sacrifice’ taking place at home of the God Particle|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en-GB}}</ref>
The video caused controversy both by creating mockery of existing theories and by fueling existing conspiracy theories about CERN activities. Given that the ritual was performed in front of a statue of a deity, some believed the ritual was satanic in nature. This further fueled theories that CERN's goal was to use their [[Large Hadron Collider]] to create a portal to hell, summon the [[antichrist]], or resurrect the ancient gods.<ref>{{cite web |last1=LaCapria |first1=Kim |title=Fact Check Fauxtography Was a Human Sacrifice Captured at CERN? |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/human-sacrifice-captured-at-cern/ |website=Snopes.com |accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>
